topics.title: Legal Issues: Recurring Medical Malpractice Topics - Six Case Examples

description.presentedBy: Presented by attorneys from the law firm of Armstrong, Donohue, Ceppos, Vaughan & Rhoades, Chtd.
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

This program will review the most common recurring issues that serve as a basis for medical malpractice litigation. These issues include differential diagnoses, informed consent, complications of treatment, poor communication, and poor record-keeping. The discussion will include short video vignettes.

 

About the Presenter

Since its inception, the focus of the law firm of Armstrong, Donohue, Ceppos, Vaughan & Rhoades has been primarily on the defense of medical negligence cases, representing countless Physicians across the broadest possible spectrum of medical specialties. Along with their defense work, the firm has provided educational sessions on a number of relevant medico-legal topics.

 

Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Recognize the most common recurring issues in medical malpractice litigation
  • Understand how these issues play out in malpractice litigation
  • Learn techniques to best avoid these issues

 

Program Schedule

5:30 p.m. Registration and light dinner

6:00 p.m. Program begins

6:30 p.m. Grace period ends – no one will be admitted after this time

8:00 p.m. Program ends

 

Accreditation Statement

MEDICAL MUTUAL Liability Insurance Society of Maryland is accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME) to provide continuing medical education for physicians.

 

Designation Statement

MEDICAL MUTUAL designates this live activity for a maximum of two (2) AMA PRA Category 1 Credit(s).™ Physicians should claim only the credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity.

topics.title: HIPAA Revisited: Data Breach Prevention and Data Breach Response for the Physician

description.presentedBy: Presented by Jeremy Krum, Esquire of Armstrong, Donohue, Ceppos, Vaughan & Rhoades, Chtd.
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

This seminar will cover cyber security and risk assessments for the Physician and medical practice group, including cyber vulnerability, business continuity, and disaster recovery planning. Participants will likewise become more familiar with data breach prevention and data breach incident response, including breach notification rules and regulations. Topics will include a review of recent ransomware and EHR encryption attacks, practice policies and practice implications.

 

About the Presenter

Jeremy Krum is a partner and shareholder at Armstrong, Donohue, Ceppos, Vaughan & Rhoades. He has been representing hospitals, Physicians, nurses and other health care providers and professional medical practice groups in Maryland and in the District of Columbia for the course of his career. He also handles matters before the Maryland Board of Physicians, D.C. Board of Medicine, and the Maryland State Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners. Mr. Krum is also  an active member of the Maryland Society for Healthcare Risk Management, and he regularly lectures and presents to Physicians, nurses and professional medical practice groups in Maryland and in the District of Columbia on medical malpractice and risk management-related issues.

 

Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Prepare for and implement cyber security assessments and cyber security planning
  • Understand HIPAA breach response procedures and breach notifications
  • Be familiar with current EMR security concerns and recent cyber security attacks
  • Understand both federal and local authority perspectives associated with HIPAA and document security

 

Program Schedule

5:30 p.m. Registration and light dinner

6:00 p.m. Program begins

6:30 p.m. Grace period ends – no one will be admitted after this time

8:00 p.m. Program ends

 

Accreditation Statement

Designation Statement

description.presentedBy: Presented by Steven Berlin, M.D. and Gregory Murray, MEDICAL MUTUAL Claims Representative
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

This new program will review closed anesthesia malpractice claims emanating from the hospital and ambulatory surgicenter. The seminar will identify common risk factors that lead to malpractice claims and offer risk management strategies on how to minimize and even avoid these risk factors.

 

Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Recognize malpractice situations involving anesthesia
  • Identify steps to minimize anesthesia risks
  • Discuss how to decrease claims based on a review of closed claims involving anesthetic care

topics.title: Primary Care: Risk Management in a Nutshell

description.presentedBy: Presented by Daniel Kohn, M.D. and Michael Doll, MEDICAL MUTUAL Risk Management Specialist
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

Whether patients present with common, everyday symptoms or more non-specific ones, Physicians can be lulled into a false sense of security and avoid a full diagnostic investigation. Similarly, delayed or deferred diagnostic efforts in patients with rare or complicated presentations can result in adverse outcomes. This program will focus on how attentive, careful and critical thinking may help avert these complications.

 

Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Heighten their awareness of potentially serious complications in patients presenting with seemingly minor or routine complaints
  • Be vigilant in closely following patients with unusual or complicated illness
  • Maintain awareness of possible complications in emotionally labile patients who are taking potentially lethal medications
  • Adhere to protocols and guidelines for obtaining and following routine screening tests

 

Program Schedule

5:30 p.m. Registration and light dinner

6:00 p.m. Program begins

6:30 p.m. Grace period ends – no one will be admitted after this time

8:00 p.m. Program ends

topics.title: OB/GYN: Risk Management in a Nutshell

description.presentedBy: Presented by Steven Berlin, M.D. and Gregory Murray, MEDICAL MUTUAL Claims Representative
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

The 2017 OB/GYN program will focus on common themes underlying the various causes of medical malpractice claims. Closed OB/GYN cases will be reviewed and analyzed from a medico-legal standpoint. The program will also address the effects of a malpractice claim on Physicians.

 

Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Identify risk issues resulting in medical malpractice claims
  • Use information provided to improve patient safety
  • Understand how to deal with involvement in a medical malpractice lawsuit

 

Program Schedule

5:30 p.m. Registration and light dinner

6:00 p.m. Program begins

description.presentedBy: Presented by Francis J. Velez, M.D. and Trace Krueger, Esquire of Baxter, Baker, Sidle & Conn, P.A.
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

Surgery is a science and art that is often imperfect. Those who practice surgery risk malpractice liability when surgical outcomes are unexpected or less than ideal. This new course focuses on how those who practice surgery can minimize their potential exposure to malpractice lawsuits.

 

Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Analyze and discuss actual surgical malpractice cases to understand how they might have been avoided or mitigated
  • Review informed consent and the role it plays in protecting surgeons from medical malpractice liability
  • Explore surgical best practices for determining whether and when to recommend surgery and/or refer patients
  • Address the importance of communication and follow-up in surgical practice as tools to minimize risk

 

Program Schedule

5:30 p.m. Registration and light dinner

6:00 p.m. Program begins

6:30 p.m. Grace period ends – no one will be admitted after this time

8:00 p.m. Program ends

description.presentedBy: Presented by Alan Malouf, M.D. and Neal Brown of Waranch & Brown, LLC
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

The focus of this new program will be identifying top risk areas in ophthalmology based on litigation experience. The course will explore methods to avoid these areas and examine best practices necessary in treating the patients who often represent these risks.

 

Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Identify three major risk areas in treating the ophthalmic patient
  • Learn risk avoidance
  • Implement best practices to decrease the risk of a poor patient outcome and medical malpractice litigation

 

Program Schedule

description.presentedBy: Presented by Daniel Kohn, M.D. and Eric Rhoades, Esquire of Armstrong, Donohue, Ceppos, Vaughan & Rhoades, Chtd.
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

This program will educate emergency Physicians who practice in Maryland on frequently encountered medico-legal issues relating to the use of electronic medical records (EMR). The discussion will aid Physicians, nurse practitioners and physician assistants in identifying these issues and developing risk management strategies relating to recurring EMR issues. Closed claims involving medical malpractice cases in the ED setting will also be discussed in the second half of the program.

 

Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Address issues unique to the electronic medical record
  • Understand how EMR platforms vary across vendors in complexity and institutional customization
  • Recognize associated risk management issues with EMR use in order to avoid diagnostic errors and miscommunication among providers
  • Review and develop strategies to more effectively employ the EMR system in current ED practice
  • Identify and mitigate risk issues in the Emergency Department

 

Program Schedule

5:30 p.m. Registration and light dinner

6:00 p.m. Program begins

6:30 p.m. Grace period ends – no one will be admitted after this time

8:00 p.m. Program ends

Designation Statement

topics.title: Pediatrics: Big Risks Come in Small Packages

description.presentedBy: Presented by Carol Plotsky, M.D. and Erica Mudd, Esquire of Armstrong, Donohue, Ceppos, Vaughan & Rhoades, Chtd.
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

This year’s pediatrics program will seek to address various medico-legal issues frequently encountered by pediatricians, nurse practitioners, physician assistants and other Physician specialists who deal predominantly with the pediatric patient. The program will address frequently encountered topics, including: the pitfalls of medical record documentation, the impact of office staff, medication prescribing practices (including psychiatric medications), informed consent, keeping PHI secure and communication.

 

Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Understand the legal implications of common issues that can arise involving clinical care, patient interactions and in connection with the medical record
  • Understand how to respond to a variety of issues that can arise in the pediatric care setting and can create both clinical and legal risk
  • Understand Maryland law (and federal law where applicable) as it applies to medico-legal issues that may be unique to the pediatric provider
  • Review and develop clinical and risk management strategies to address frequently occurring medical and legal issues relating to communication in the pediatric health care setting

 

Program Schedule

5:30 p.m. Registration and light dinner

6:00 p.m. Program begins

6:30 p.m. Grace period ends – no one will be admitted after this time

8:00 p.m. Program ends

topics.title: Case in Point III: Failure to Diagnose

description.presentedBy: Authored by members of MEDICAL MUTUAL’s risk management, claims, communications, policy information and legal departments
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

Case in Point III examines closed medical malpractice claims that have diagnostic error as their core allegation. The selected cases illustrate an all-too-common theme presented in a variety of clinical situations where a Physician’s failure to diagnose a patient properly led to a lawsuit.

Participants who successfully complete Case in Point III will receive the same 5% premium discount that they would receive for attending a live activity.

NOTE

If you have previously completed the Case In Point III home study course, you are NOT eligible to receive a premium discount or CME Credits by taking it again in 2017.

Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Identify what constitutes an allegation of failure to diagnose in a malpractice lawsuit
  • Recognize the role of the medical record in preventing diagnostic errors
  • Increase Physician-patient communication and participation in their own health care
  • Implement changes in practice to minimize delay in diagnosis or failure to diagnose


How Case in Point Works

Participants will receive a copy of the Case in Point book by mail. To satisfy the requirements of the course, participants must read the book and complete a short post-test at the conclusion. Participants will also be asked to complete an evaluation form. The finished post-test and evaluation form should be sent back to MEDICAL MUTUAL in the postage paid envelope included with the book.

Completed tests and evaluations are due no later than September 29, 2017.
The cut-off date to register for Case in Point is August 25, 2017.


Accreditation Statement

MEDICAL MUTUAL Liability Insurance Society of Maryland is accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education
(ACCME) to provide continuing medical education for physicians.

Designation Statement

MEDICAL MUTUAL Liability Insurance Society of Maryland designates this enduring material for a maximum of two (2) AMA PRA Category 1 Credit(s).™ Physicians should claim only the credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity.

description.presentedBy: Authored by members of MEDICAL MUTUAL’s risk management, claims, communications, policy information and legal departments
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

Case in Point II is our second risk management publication featuring a series of closed-claim scenarios that focus on issues involving medical record documentation. The selected cases serve to provide the reader with situations in which poor or non-existent documentation created patient safety issues and allegations of negligent treatment for the Physician.

Participants who successfully complete Case in Point II will receive the same 5% premium discount that they would receive for attending a live activity.


NOTE

If you have previously completed the Case In Point II home study course, you are NOT eligible to receive a premium discount or CME Credits by taking it again in 2017.


Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Identify weaknesses in the medical record that can result in miscommunication and poor patient outcomes
  • Understand the role of the medical record as crucial evidence in medical malpractice litigation
  • Recognize how strong documentation can prevent litigation


How Case in Point Works

Participants will receive a copy of the Case in Point book by mail. To satisfy the requirements of the course, participants must read the book and complete a short post-test at the conclusion. Participants will also be asked to complete an evaluation form. The finished post-test and evaluation form should be sent back to MEDICAL MUTUAL in the postage paid envelope included with the book.

Completed tests and evaluations are due no later than September 29, 2017.

The cut-off date to register for Case in Point is August 25, 2017.

description.presentedBy: Authored by members of MEDICAL MUTUAL’s risk management, claims, communications, policy information and legal departments
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

Case in Point is a publication consisting of closed medical malpractice claims focusing on the larger issue of communication within the health care setting. The cases serve as illustrations of how good communication might have made the difference in a patient’s ultimate outcome or the defensibility of a claim.

Participants who successfully complete Case in Point will receive the same 5% premium discount that they would receive for attending a live activity.


NOTE

If you have previously completed the Case In Point home study course, you are NOT eligible to receive a premium discount or CME Credits by taking it again in 2017.


Objectives

Upon completion of this live activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Understand how communication breakdowns can lead to patient injury and medical malpractice lawsuits
  • Gain added insight into the prevention of communication errors
  • Implement strategies to improve communication skills


How Case in Point Works

Participants will receive a copy of the Case in Point book by mail. To satisfy the requirements of the course, participants must read the book and complete a short post-test at the conclusion. Participants will also be asked to complete an evaluation form. The finished post-test and evaluation form should be sent back to MEDICAL MUTUAL in the postage paid envelope included with the book.

Completed tests and evaluations are due no later than September 29, 2017.

topics.title: Opioid Prescribing: Avoid the Pain - A Free Online Program

description.presentedBy: Presented by John T. Sly, Esquire of Waranch & Brown, LLC
description.overviewHtml:
Overview

It is important that both the health care provider and the patient be aware of their responsibilities in prescribing and using opioid medications. An opioid treatment agreement between patient and provider will help to clarify expectations. This course will focus on effective communication skills as well as the potential risks and benefits of opioids and when and how to initiate, maintain, modify, continue or discontinue opioid therapy.


NOTE

This program is worth a maximum of one CME Credit. It does NOT provide the 5% premium discount.


About the Presenter

﻿John T. Sly is a trial attorney and partner at Waranch & Brown, LLC. His practice focuses on the aggressive defense of Physicians and health care facilities throughout Maryland. He has successfully tried to verdict numerous high-dollar cases and has argued before state and federal appellate courts. Mr. Sly is AV rated by Martindale Hubbell — the highest rating for attorneys. Mr. Sly has also been elected to the American Board of Trial Advocates (ABOTA).﻿


Objectives

Upon completion of this Internet activity, participants will be better able to:

  • Understand the recommended steps to be taken prior to initiating long-term opioid therapy
  • Understand the recommended steps to be taken upon initiating long-term opioid therapy
  • Use screening tools to assess the baseline risk of opioid addiction/abuse
  • Implement the recommended methods for follow-up evaluation and for ensuring appropriate use of medications


Accreditation Statement 

MEDICAL MUTUAL Liability Insurance Society of Maryland is accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME) to provide continuing medical education for physicians.


Designation Statement

MEDICAL MUTUAL Liability Insurance Society of Maryland designates this enduring material for a maximum of two (2) AMA PRA Category 1 Credit(s).™ Physicians should claim only the credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity.
